Body - 0.74 W/kg | hac = Not supported | references = {{cite web |url=http://www.google.com/googlephone/NexusOneOwnersGuide.pdf |title=Nexus One Owner's Manual NOOGG-220-101 |date=2010-06-16 |work=google.com |publisher=Google Inc |pages=17â19 |format=PDF |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wvL9MTmm |archivedate=2011-03-03 |accessdate=2011-03-03}}[http://twitter.com/googlenexus/status/16974464310845440 2.3 coming to nexus one confirmed by google]{{cite web|url=http://zitseng.com/archives/2680|accessdate=January 17, 2010|title=The Nexus One Arrives}}{{cite web|url=https://fjallfoss.fcc.gov/oetcf/eas/reports/ViewExhibitReport.cfm?mode=Exhibits&RequestTimeout=500&calledFromFrame=N&application_id=136120&fcc_id=%27NM8PB99100|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=OET List Exhibits Report|publisher=[[Federal Communications Commission]]}}{{cite web |url=http://forums.t-mobile.com/t5/Google-Nexus/Nexus-One-Specifications/td-p/288027 |title=Nexus One Specifications |date=2010-01-06 |work=forums.t-mobile.com |publisher=T-Mobile USA, Inc |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wvLZAR0q |archivedate=2011-03-03 |accessdate=2011-03-03}} }} The '''Nexus One''' (codenamed '''HTC Passion''')[http://www.intomobile.com/2009/12/13/photo-the-nexus-one-aka-htc-passion-aka-google-phone-has-leaked.html Photo: The Nexus One, aka HTC Passion, aka Google Phone, has leaked] was [[Google]]'s flagship [[smartphone]] manufactured by Taiwan's [[HTC Corporation]]. It became available on January 5, 2010 and uses the [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[open source]] [[mobile operating system]].{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/phone/static/en_US-nexusone_tech_specs.html|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Nexus One Phone|publisher=[[Google]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/phone/|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Nexus One Phone|work=Google.com|publisher=[[Google]]|year=2010}}{{Cite news|first=Rob|last=Jackson|url=http://phandroid.com/2010/01/05/nexus-one-now-available-for-verizonvodafone-too-soon/|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Nexus One Now Available...|work=[[Phandroid]]|publisher=[[Phandroid]]|date=January 5, 2010}} Features of the phone include the ability to transcribe voice to text,{{Cite news|first=Jason|last=Mick|url=http://www.dailytech.com/An+iPhone+Slayer+Google+Unveils+the+Nexus+One/article17291.htm|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Google Unveils the Nexus One, Coming to Verizon in Spring 2010|date=January 5, 2010|newspaper=[[Daily Tech]]|publisher=[[Daily Tech]]}}{{Cite news|first=Joshua|last=Topolsky|url=http://www.engadget.com/2010/01/04/nexus-one-review/|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Nexus One Review|date=January 4, 2010|newspaper=[[Engadget]]|publisher=[[AOL News]]}} an additional microphone for [[noise-canceling microphone|dynamic noise suppression]],{{cite web|last= Arrington |first= Michael |url= http://www.techcrunch.com/2010/01/05/google-nexus-one-the-techcrunch-review/ |title= Google Nexus One: The TechCrunch Review |publisher= Techcrunch.com |date= 2010-01-05 |accessdate= 2010-01-18}} and voice guided [[turn-by-turn navigation]] to drivers.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/googlephone/nexusone-userguide.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Nexus One User Guide|publisher=[[Google]]}}{{Cite news|first=Dana|last=Blankenhorn|url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/open-source/?p=5531|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Google building a base under Android with Nexus One|date=December 30, 2009|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]}} The device is sold [[SIM lock|SIM unlocked]] (not restricted to use on a single network provider). Google offered [[T-Mobile USA]] and [[AT&T Mobility|AT&T]] versions of the phone online in the United States before closing the online store in July 2010. A version for use on [[Vodafone]] (European) networks was announced on 26 April 2010, available in the UK on 30 April 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/start/media_relations/news/local_press_releases/uk_press_releases/2010/nexus_one.html|accessdate=May 1, 2010|title=Google Nexus One Launches on Vodafone UK|publisher=[[Vodafone]]|year=2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On March 16, 2010, the Nexus One device became available on the Google web store for sale in [[Canada]] for use with most Canadian carriers.{{cite web|url=http://googlenexusoneboard.blogspot.com/2010/03/nexus-one-now-compatible-with-at-3g.html|title=Nexus One now compatible with the AT&T 3G network and shipping to Canada|publisher=[[Google]]|year=2010}} In May 2010 Google announced the closing of the web store, with the intention to distribute the phone through partners around the world.[http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/05/nexus-one-changes-in-availability.html Nexus One changes in availability] The bootloader of the phone is unlockable, see [[#Platform development, hacking, and modification|below]]. Apple is targeting the Nexus One in a patent lawsuit against HTC.[http://www.slipperybrick.com/2010/03/apple-targets-nexus-one-maybe-google-in-lawsuit/ Apple Targets Nexus One, Maybe Google in Lawsuit - SlipperyBrick.com][http://www.phonesreview.co.uk/2010/03/14/nexus-one-to-blame-for-apple-htc-lawsuit/ Nexus One to Blame for Apple, HTC Lawsuit Â» Phone Reviews]http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9164938 ==History== A trademark application for the name "Nexus One" was filed by Google, Inc. on December 10, 2009. The Nexus One trademark was filed in International Trademark Class 9 for "Computer & Software Products & Electrical & Scientific Products" with description of "Mobile phones".{{cite web|url=http://www.androidos.in/2009/12/google-gets-nexus-one-trademarked.html |title=Exclusive: Google files for 'Nexus One' Trademark |publisher=Androidos.in |date=2009-12-16 |accessdate=2010-01-05}} On 15 March 2010 it was announced that the application had been declined due to the mark already being granted on December 30, 2008 to Integra Telecom.{{cite web|url=http://news.nexus-one.co.uk/post/449889239/google-runs-into-a-problem-with-nexus-one-trademark |title=Google runs into a problem with Nexus One trademark application |publisher=nexus-one.co.uk |date=2010-03-15 |accessdate=2010-03-15}} On December 12, 2009, Google confirmed in a blog post that they had begun internal testing of the device.{{cite web|url=http://googlemobile.blogspot.com/2009/12/android-dogfood-diet-for-holidays.html |title=Official Google Mobile Blog: An Android dogfood diet for the holidays |publisher=Googlemobile.blogspot.com |date=2009-12-12 |accessdate=2010-01-05}} Google stated that a "mobile lab device" had been given to its employees, at that time Google had not yet confirmed that a device would be sold to consumers. Wireless phone and data services for the device were not activated nor billed to Google; it was up to the employees to activate and pay for wireless service on their own.{{cite web|url=http://www.nexusoneforum.net/forum/nexus-one-google-phone-news/58-how-do-googlers-activate-nexus-one-just-like-you-i.html |title=How do Googlers activate the Nexus One? Just like you and I. - Nexus One Forum - Google Phone Forum |publisher=Nexus One Forum |date=2009-12-22 |accessdate=2010-01-05}} Isa Dick Hackett, daughter of [[Philip K. Dick]], and several bloggers believe the name Nexus One is a reference to the novel ''[[Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?]]'' by [[Philip K. Dick]], in which there are androids with a model designation of "Nexus-6".{{cite news|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/12/15/is-the-google-phone-an-unauthorized-replicant/ |title=Is the Google Phone an Unauthorized Replicant? |publisher=nytimes.com |date=2009-12-15 |accessdate=2010-05-31 | first=Jenna | last=Wortham}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2009/12/nexus-did-google-dream-of-electric-lawsuits/ |title=Nexus: Did Google Dream of Electric Lawsuits? |publisher=wired.com |date=2009-12-16 |accessdate=2010-05-31}} ==Availability== ===In the United States=== The Nexus One was released on January 5, 2010. The phone was sold via Google's website, at a price of $529 without a plan or contract, or a subsidized $179 when purchased with a [[T-Mobile USA]] two year contract.{{cite web|url=http://www.androidtapp.com/google-phone-nexus-one-available-for-sale/|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Google Phone Nexus One Available for Sale!|publisher=[[AndroidTapp.com]]|date=January 5, 2010}} Google announced in May 2010 that the online store would close, and the phone would be offered in retail stores.[http://www.mobilemarketingnews.co.uk/Google_Pulls_Nexus_One_from_Online_Retail_65179130268.html Mobile Marketing news: Google Pulls Nexus One from Online Retail][http://news.cnet.com/8301-30684_3-20005015-265.html CNET Google turns Nexus One strategy upside down] As of July 21, 2010, the Nexus One is available through retail stores from i wireless[http://www.iwireless.com/phones_detail.asp?pid=171 i wireless - Phones - Google Nexus One â 3G] and Cincinnati Bell.[http://www.cincinnatibell.com/consumer/wireless/phones_and_devices/?id=htc_nexusone Cincinnati Bell Wireless Phones & Devices Cincinnati] ===={{anchor|T-Mobile}} T-Mobile USA==== Several plans were available for subsidized phones: * $69.99 per month rate, which includes 500 minutes with unlimited nights and weekends, and unlimited e-mail/data. *No [[SMS]] included * $79.99 per month rate, which includes 500 minutes with unlimited nights and weekends, unlimited [[SMS]], and unlimited e-mail/data. * $89.99 and unlimited minutes, unlimited [[SMS]], and unlimited e-mail/data. Unsubsidized phones had no such limitation.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/phone/choose?locale=en_US&s7e=|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Nexus One Phone|publisher=[[Google]]}} {{Dead link|date=March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.t-mobile.com/shop/plans/cell-phone-plans-detail.aspx?tp=tb1&rateplan=Even-More-Plus-Unlimited-Talk-Text-Web |title=Even More Plus Unlimited Talk + Text + Web Rate Plan: Even More Plus Unlimited Talk + Text + Web details |publisher=T-mobile.com |date=2008-12-07 |accessdate=2010-01-18}} The $179 T-Mobile USA price is only for individuals who are not currently under contract with T-Mobile USA. If one currently has a T-Mobile USA contract, the price of the phone rises to $279.99.{{cite web|url=http://gizmodo.com/5436673/leaked-nexus-one-documents-530-unlocked-180-with-t+mobile|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Leaked Nexus One Documents: $530 Unlocked, $180 With T-Mobile - Nexus one|publisher=[[Gizmodo]]|date=December 29, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.t-mobile.com/shop/Plans/Cell-Phone-Plans.aspx?catgroup=EvenMorePlus|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Cell Phone Plans: T-Mobile rate plans-cell phones, wireless plans, BlackBerry, Sidekick|publisher=[[T-mobile]]}} In addition, tax may be charged depending on the state to which the device is shipped. Each order is shipped with free FedEx Overnight shipping (although, when checking your order status with FedEX you may note that it was sent FedEx 2-Day), with indirect signature required. With engraving delivery can be delayed up to 72 hours. Google removed a price level of $379.99 for current T-mobile USA customers who had a data plan. Those who ordered the phone for $379.99 were refunded $100USD. T-Mobile USA contract plans cost $20 per month more than non-contract plans. For unlocked phones, T-Mobile USA offers a Prepaid SIM Card Activation Kit. T-Mobile USA's website offers it at discounted price of $6.99{{cite web|accessdate=2010-12-06|url=http://www.t-mobile.com/shop/Phones/cell-phone-detail.aspx?class=prepaid&cell-phone=Prepaid-T-Mobile-SIM-Activation-Kit|author=T-Mobile|title=T-Mobile Prepaid SIM Card Activation Kit}} (or free{{cite web|url=http://www.t-mobile.com/shop/phones/Cell-Phone-Detail.aspx?cell-phone=T-Mobile-SIM-Card|accessdate=2010-12-06|author=T-Mobile|title=T-Mobile SIM Card Activation Kit with contract}} with a 2 year contract). Voice-only no-contract plans are available at several price points including $100 for 1000 minutes good for a year. Airtime is sold online, by phone, or at retail stores. On 18 Oct 2010, T-Mobile USA introduced a Data Day Pass which allows Prepaid users to purchase unlimited data access for 24 hours for $1.49.{{cite web|author=Wireless Advisor|date=15 Oct 2010|url= http://forums.wirelessadvisor.com/t-mobile-forum/79322-t-mobiles-new-pre-paid-plans.html|accessdate=2010-12-04|title=T-Mobile new Prepaid Plans}}{{cite web|url=http://www.t-mobile.com/shop/plans/prepaid-plans.aspx|accessdate=2010-12-04|author=T-Mobile|title=T-Mobile Prepaid Calling Plans}} ====AT&T==== A version of the Nexus One with support for UMTS 850/1900/2100 MHz was first made available on March 16, 2010. (These UMTS bands are used by AT&T in the U.S. and Rogers in Canada.) It was only available from the Google Phone Webstore unsubsidized for $529.{{cite web|url=http://www.afterdawn.com/news/article.cfm/2010/03/17/3g_nexus_one_now_available_from_google|accessdate=Marth, 2010|title= Google upgrades Nexus One to work on AT&T's 3G network in latest swipe at Apple's iPhone}} This version remained SIM unlocked. ====Verizon==== When the Nexus One was first announced in January 2010, Google said that a Verizon model would be made available later in the year.{{cite web |title=Will the Sprint Google Nexus One be dropped soon too? |url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/cell-phones/will-the-sprint-google-nexus-one-be-dropped-soon-too/3759 |author=Matthew Miller | date= May 6, 2010 |publisher=ZDNet.com }} But in late April 2010, Google announced that "We won't be selling a Nexus One with Verizon ...",{{cite web | date=April 26, 2010 |title=Verizon dumps Nexus One for Droid Incredible? |author=Bonnie Cha |url=http://www.cnet.com/8301-19736_1-20003397-251.html |publisher=cnet.com}} and told users who wanted the Nexus One on Verizon to get the HTC [[Droid Incredible]], "a powerful new Android phone and a cousin of the Nexus One that is similarly feature-packed."{{cite web |url=http://googlenexusoneboard.blogspot.com/2010/04/update-on-nexus-one-partnerships.html | date=April 26, 2010 |title=An update on Nexus One partnerships |publisher=Google}} ====Sprint==== A Sprint version of the Nexus One ([[CDMA2000]]) was announced on March 17, 2010, without giving specific availability dates or pricing. The press release states a commitment to "simple" pricing and references the current pricing structure.{{cite web|url=http://newsreleases.sprint.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=127149&p=irol-newsArticle_newsroom&ID=1403426|accessdate=March 18, 2010|title=Sprint News Release: Nexus One from Google Coming to Sprint; Availability Date Announced Soon}} On May 10, 2010 Sprint announced that it too, like Verizon, would not release the Nexus One, instead opting to release the more robust [[HTC EVO 4G]] in current 3G and expanding 4G markets.{{cite web|url=http://www.phonescoop.com/news/item.php?n=5952|accessdate=May 11, 2010|title=Sprint Bails On The Google Nexus One}} ===In Canada=== On March 16, 2010 Google officially released the Nexus One for purchase by Canadian consumers, offering two versions of the handset that will operate on either [[Bell Canada|Bell]], [[Telus]] or [[Rogers Wireless|Rogers]]' 3G networks (UMTS band 2 and 5) or alternatively on [[Wind Mobile]] and [[Videotron]] (UMTS band 4/AWS).{{cite web|url=http://googlenexusoneboard.blogspot.com/2010/03/nexus-one-now-compatible-with-at-3g.html|accessdate=March 16, 2010|title=Nexus One now compatible with the AT&T 3G network and shipping to Canada|publisher=[[Google]]}} On September 9, 2010, [[VidÃ©otron]] included the Nexus One as part of their launch smartphone selection for its new AWS [[HSPA+]] network. In November 2010, [[Mobilicity]] listed the "Nexus One by Google" on their "Products - Phones" web page.{{cite web|url=http://store.mobilicity.ca/product.asp?pf_id=37102M|title=Produces - Phones|publisher=mobilicity.ca}} This is also on the AWS network. ===In France=== On May 18, 2010 the Nexus One was made available for purchase through the SFR web portal. ===In Italy=== Beginning set for May 25, the Nexus One availability was then postponed to May 28, 2010. The phone is sold over the [[Vodafone Italy]] shops and website. ===In Australia=== On July 2, 2010 the Nexus One was available for purchase through the Vodafone AUS website. The sale only lasted approximately 3 weeks as stock levels ordered were a minimum. The phone was also available through non telco resellers for use on any network. ===In New Zealand=== As of January 20, 2011, the Nexus One is still{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.co.nz/shop/mobileDetails.jsp?skuId=sku8540042&voucherCode=&selectionKey=mobile&menuKey=mnit2400019|title=Vodafone NZ online store, Nexus One listing}} available for order from [[Vodafone NZ]] as an unlocked device for $979 outright, or $679 on a 2-year contract. ===Worldwide=== Around Spring 2010, Google launched a Vodafone model in Europe, with plans to expand the phone to other carriers and international markets in due course.{{Cite news|url=http://technologizer.com/googlephone/|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=|newspaper=[[Technologizer]]|publisher=[[Technologizer]]|date=January 5, 2010}} Google is making the phone available for delivery to the [[UK]], [[Singapore]], and [[Hong Kong]], although native carrier tie-ups have not been finalized for these countries, and the phone will be shipped from the US. Customers ordering from the UK are charged $29.65 international shipping and an optional $19.00 for an extra AC adaptor, with an additional 17.5% [[European Union Value Added Tax|VAT]]. Singapore applies 7% [[Goods and Services Tax (Singapore)|GST]], while Hong Kong does not add any additional taxes.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/phone/static/en_US-customs_duties_taxes_estimates.html|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Nexus One: Estimate your customs duties and taxes|publisher=[[Google]]}} Although the Nexus One will not ship outside these countries for a few months, two French websites started selling it (with a carrier plan) on February 15, 2010. Phones ordered from Google in Singapore are currently being shipped from the US at the customers expense.{{cite web|url=http://www.angryangmo.com/2010/01/06/how-to-buy-google-nexus-one-phone-singapore/|title=How To Buy A Google Nexus One Phone In Singapore}} On 26 April 2010, the Nexus One became available for pre-order on the Vodafone UK website.[http://shop.vodafone.co.uk/shop/mobile-phone/google-nexus-one?WT_ref=INT-Hmpg-Lyr2-Pym-Phns-16 Nexus One - Buy the Nexus One Mobile phone] Contracts started from Â£35 per month with the phone showing as free. This was a first for Google, as customers need not order from the google.com/phone website. Vodafone predict initial orders started arriving on 3 May 2010, and the phone also became available for order in store from 30 April 2010.{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2010/apr/26/vodafone-nexus-one-google-phone | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Vodafone to start selling Google Nexus One mobile â but prices disappoint | first=Richard | last=Wray | date=April 26, 2010}} On 1 July 2010, Vodafone Australia announced that they would make the Nexus One available to its customers, first come first served, on the $79 cap across 24 months.{{cite web |url=http://www.techworld.com.au/article/351802/vodafone_launches_google_nexus_one_android_phone |title=Vodafone launches Google's Nexus One Android phone |author=Gedda, Rodney |date=1 July 2010 |work=TechWorld, Australia |publisher=IDG Communications |accessdate=22 April 2011}} On 10 July 2010, the Nexus One was launched in South Korea with KT as its service provider.{{cite web |url=http://www.show.co.kr/index.asp?code=AHI0000&jurl=http://www.show.co.kr/sbrand2/nex/notice/notice_list.asp |title=[SHOW] ì¼ëë¬¸ì´ë¤}} First 4,000 pre-orders were started to be sent to respective customers, with 100 being picked to activate it on launch event held in 10th. The Nexus One will go on sale nationwide on 17 July 2010. Although the European, Australian and New Zealand Nexus One phones sold by Vodafone are not locked to the network of the provider, most of them are locked to a special Vodafone-specific system software, making it impossible to receive updates from Google. Vodafone UK are making 2.2 available as a FOTA update, as of the end of July 2010.[http://help.vodafone.co.uk/system/selfservice.controller?CMD=BROWSE_TOPIC&PARTITION_ID=1&CONFIGURATION=1058&SIDE_LINK_SUB_TOPIC_ID=213651&SIDE_LINK_TOPIC_ID=154737&TOPIC_ID=213651&TOPIC_TYPE=0&STARTING_ID=0&TOPIC_NAME=Android#a=2298620&t=213651 Android software upgrade - Help - Vodafone] ==Hardware== [[Image:Nexus one screen microscope.jpg|thumb|300px|right|''PenTile matrix pixel arrangement of the AMOLED screen'']] At time of launch, the Nexus One had a 3.7 inch [[Active-matrix OLED|AMOLED]] screen with [[PenTile]] matrix pixel arrangement.{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2010/03/iphones-lcd-screen-beats-nexus-ones-oled-display|accessdate=March 3, 2010|title=iPhone's LCD Screen Beats Nexus One's OLED Display|publisher=Wired}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stealthcopter.com/blog/2010/06/nexus-ones-amoled-screen-under-the-microscope|accessdate=June 11, 2010|title=Nexus One's AMOLED screen under the microscope|publisher=stealthcopter.com}} The [[raster graphics|raster]] resolution is 480x800 pixels, however each pixel in the PenTile RGBG display is represented by only two subpixels on average, using [[subpixel rendering]] rather than the three found in most displays, meeting the definition of WVGA according to the Video Electronics Standards Association specifications for measuring resolution.{{cite web|url=http://www.nouvoyance.com/files/pdf/measuring-pentile-display-resolution-vesa-standards.pdf|accessdate=March 4, 2011|title=Application Note Measuring Display Resolution with Contrast Modulation Methodology|publisher=Nouvoyance}} Citing supply shortages of AMOLED displays, HTC announced on July 26, 2010 that the Nexus One would begin using Super LCD display technology instead of AMOLED. The Super LCD display was described as having greater power efficiency and color accuracy than the AMOLED display, while sacrificing the lauded color saturation and deep blacks of the original display. As of January 15, 2011 or earlier, all Nexus Ones available via Brightstar, Google's worldwide distribution partner for Android development phones, shipped with Super LCD instead of AMOLED. The [[touchscreen#Capacitive|capacitive touchscreen]] which uses the [[Synaptics]] ClearPad 2000 sensor{{cite web|url=http://www.synaptics.com/about/press/press-releases/synaptics-clearpad-on-nexus-one-smartphone|title=Synaptics ClearPadâ¢ on Nexus One Smartphone|author=Synaptics Press Center|date=11Jan2010|accessdate=2010-05-24}} supports [[multi-touch]] gestures limited to single finger input and [[Gesture-enhanced single-touch|2x1D two finger gestures]].{{cite web|url=http://www.synaptics.com/sites/default/files/Product_Brief_CP2000_01_0.pdf|title=Synaptics ClearPad 2000 Product Brief|accessdate=2010-05-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.neowin.net/news/nexus-one-has-a-major-multitouch-problem|accessdate=March 6, 2010|title=Nexus One has a major multitouch problem|publisher=[[Neowin]]}}{{cite web|url=http://lukehutch.wordpress.com/2009/01/10/full-working-multitouch-on-the-t-mobile-g1-android-phone/|title=The REAL reason for no multitouch on the G1 at time of release|author=Luke Hutchison|date=10Jan2009|accessdate=2010-05-24}}The main technichal(sic) problem is that the Synaptics screen is not a true 2D multitouch device. It is a 2x1D device It has an illuminated [[trackball]] which can emit different colors of light based on the type of notification being received. A voice processor developed by [[Audience (telecom company)|Audience]] uses a second microphone (on the back) to suppress background noise during phone conversations.{{cite web|url=http://mobile.venturebeat.com/2010/01/08/the-magical-chip-that-delivers-nexus-ones-call-quality/ |title=The magical chip that delivers Nexus Oneâs call quality | VentureBeat |publisher=Mobile.venturebeat.com |date=2010-01-08 |accessdate=2010-01-18}} A 4-conductor TRRS style [[TRS connector|3.5mm stereo headset jack]] is also provided, adding microphone and pause/resume/next/previous functions to the stereo earphones. The phone features a 5.0 megapixel auto-focus camera with LED flash and digital zoom, GPS receiver, [[Bluetooth 2.0]], and [[IEEE 802.11|802.11b/g]] Wi-Fi abilities.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/phone/static/en_US-nexusone_tech_specs.html |title=Nexus One Phone - Feature overview & Technical specifications |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-18}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/phone/detail/nexus-one |title=Nexus One - Google Phone Gallery |publisher=Google.com |accessdate=2010-10-12}} The [[Snapdragon (processor)|Snapdragon]] processor allows for many advanced abilities including [[720p]] video playback.{{Cite news|first=Steven|last=Musil|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-10431742-1.html|accessdate=January 10, 2010|title=Nexus One's hardware estimated to cost $175|newspaper=[[CNET News]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive|2010 CBS Interactive Inc.]]|date=January 10, 2010}}{{cite press release |title=Google Nexus One Carries $174.15 Materials Cost, iSuppli Teardown Reveal |publisher=[[Isuppli|2010 iSuppli Corporation.]]|date=January 8, 2010 |url=http://www.isuppli.com/News/Pages/Google-Nexus-One-Carries-$17415-Materials-Cost-iSuppli-Teardown-Reveals.aspx |accessdate=January 10, 2010|quote=The Nexus One, sold with the Google brand name but manufactured by HTC Corp., carries a Bill Of Material (BOM) of $174.15}} There is built in hardware [[Parsing|decoding]] for [[H.263]], [[H.264]] and [[MPEG-4 Part 2|MPEG-4]] video, and can play [[MP3]], [[AAC+]], [[Ogg Vorbis]], [[WAV]], and [[MIDI]] audio, and display [[JPEG]], [[GIF]], [[Portable Network Graphics|PNG]], and [[BMP file format|BMP]] image formats. It has a [[micro USB]] port which conforms to the [[GSMA]] [[Universal Charging Solution]] instead of the common [[MicroUSB|mini-USB]] port, or HTC's mini-USB compatible format ([[ExtUSB]]). The [[microSD]] card slot allows expansion up to 32{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=http://www.google.com/googlephone/NexusOneOwnersGuide.pdf |title=Nexus One Phone - Owners Guide |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-05}} gigabytes of card storage. Applications can be installed either to the 512 MB internal flash memory, of which 190 MB are available for that purpose, or to the microSD card. A third party analysis by [[iSuppli]] estimates the cost of hardware components to be around $175. ===Cellular=== As of March 16, 2010, there are two versions of the Nexus One.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/phone/static/en_US-nexusone_tech_specs.html|accessdate=May 29, 2010|title=Nexus One Phone - Feature overview & Technical specifications|publisher=[[Google]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Both versions of the Nexus One cover most major [[GSM]] and [[3G]] providers in the US, Europe and Asia. On both phones, the GSM radio frequencies covered are 850 MHz, 900 MHz, 1800 MHz, and 1900 MHz. The original Nexus One (PB99100) also came along with [[UMTS frequency bands]] 1 (2100 MHz), 4 (1700 MHz), and 8 (900 MHz),{{Cite news|first=John|last=Stokes|url=http://arstechnica.com/gadgets/news/2010/01/google-android-event-liveblog.ars|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Liveblog: Google Android Press Event|newspaper=[[Ars Technica]]|publisher=Ars Technica|date=January 5, 2010}} allowing it to access 3G throughout Europe, as well as on [[T-Mobile USA]] and [[WIND Mobile]] and [[Mobilicity]] and [[Videotron]] in Canada. The second version of the Nexus One (PB99110) supports [[UMTS frequency bands]] 1 (2100 MHz), 2 (1900 MHz), and 5 (850 MHz), allowing it to access 3G in most of Europe, as well as on [[AT&T Mobility]] in the USA and [[Rogers Wireless]], [[Fido Solutions]], [[Bell Mobility]], and [[Telus Mobility]] in Canada. The second version of the Nexus One also works on [[Telecom New Zealand]]'s [[XT Mobile Network]], [[Telcel]]'s 3G Network and [[Telstra]]'s [[Next G|Next-G]] network. The UMTS radio supports [[High Speed Packet Access]]; [[High-Speed Downlink Packet Access|HSDPA]] at 7.2 Mbit/s, and [[High-Speed Uplink Packet Access|HSUPA]] at 2 Mbit/s. For More info on which Model of the Nexus One you have and the differences between the two please see this link. http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/android/thread?tid=395c29e6b9cab6bc&hl=en ==Software== {{Main|Android (operating system)}} The Nexus One was released with Android 2.1 Eclair. Later, an OTA update of Android 2.2 Froyo was released, which introduced a number of highlights:{{cite web|title=Android 2.24 Platform Highlights|author=|publisher=Google|date=|url=http://developer.android.com/sdk/android-2.2-highlights.html|accessdate=2010-05-23}} a new Home screen, support for Adobe Flash 10.1, better Microsoft Exchange support, Wi-Fi tethering, SD-card installable applications, cloud to device messaging for two-way push sync functionality and an overall 2-5x performance improvement. The integrated Media Gallery, developed by [[Cooliris]], provides several new features allowing the user to browse, edit, and share photos and videos on the phone. The Nexus One ships with non-removable third-party [[foistware]] apps, including "Amazon MP3" and "Facebook".{{fact|date=October 2011}} As of January 28, 2011, Android-based phones have access to more than 210,000 applications through the [[Android Market]].{{cite web|url=http://www.androlib.com/appstats.aspx |title=Android Market Statistics |publisher=AndroLib.com|accessdate=2011-01-28}} The Nexus One OTA update to Gingerbread (2.3.3) started on 23rd February 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsden.net/nexus-one-android-2-3-3-gingerbread-gr140-official-update-download-6795/ |title=Nexus One Android 2.3.3 Gingerbread Official Update |publisher=NewsDen}} The Nexus One currently runs the Google [[Android (operating system)|Android]] 2.3.6 Gingerbread operating system.{{cite web|url=http://www.androidcentral.com/nexus-one-updated-android-236-grk39f |title=Nexus One updated to Android 2.3.6 (GRK39F) |publisher=Android Central}} Google has stated it will not update the Nexus One to [[Android (operating system)|Android]] 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich) saying the hardware is âtoo oldâ,http://techcrunch.com/2011/10/26/the-nexus-one-isnt-invited-to-the-ice-cream-sandwich-social/ however, third party ROMs are expected.http://androidandme.com/2011/10/news/nexus-one-too-old-to-be-upgraded-to-ice-cream-sandwich/http://mobiputing.com/2011/10/google-wont-release-android-4-0-for-the-nexus-one-but-someone-else-probably-will/ ==Platform development, hacking, and modification== The Nexus One ships with an unlockable [[bootloader]]{{cite web|author=Romain Guy|date=5Jan2010|title=Nexus One for platform development|url=http://groups.google.com/group/android-platform/browse_thread/thread/2fd6d1c9963485f8/872080d49990b649|accessdate=2010-03-03}}The bootloader is unlockable out of the box, no need to crack it. allowing developers to participate in the Android Open Source Project in addition to developing applications.{{cite web |url=http://source.android.com |title=Android Open Source Project |accessdate=22 April 2011}} The Nexus One operating system can be unlocked and flashed with the [[fastboot]] utility which is part of the Android Open Source Project. Fastboot runs on Linux, Mac OS, or Windows and accesses the Nexus One through the [[USB]] port. The [[bootloader]] of the Nexus One is accessed by holding the [[trackball]] while powering up the device.{{cite web |url=http://androidandme.com/2010/01/hacks/video-how-to-unlock-and-root-a-nexus-one/ |title=How to unlock and root a Nexus One |author=Taylor Wimberly |date=11 January 2010 |publisher=AndroidandMe.com |accessdate=2010-02-20}} Users are able to gain [[root user|root]] privileges on the device by unlocking its [[bootloader]] using the [[fastboot]] command "fastboot oem unlock."{{cite web|url=http://hydtechblog.com/2010/01/05/getting-root-on-your-new-nexus-one-android-google-phone/ |title=Getting root on your new Nexus One Android Google Phone | HydTech |publisher=Hydtechblog.com |date=2010-01-05 |accessdate=2010-01-18}} or by uploading specially crafted data packages via the Android debug bridge {{cite web|author=Constrabus|date=26Jun2010|title=[Tutorial] Root FRF85B/FRF83/FRF72(T-Mo/AT&T) Without Unlocking (100% Confirmed)|url=http://forum.xda-developers.com/showthread.php?t=710842}} without the need to unlock the bootloader. Unlocking the bootloader or rooting the device allows the user to install non-official firmware images. Additionally, obtaining root privileges enables a user to override protected operating system features, and install arbitrary software. If using the fastboot command to unlock the bootloader to gain root through use of a custom firmware image, the user is presented with a Google-created screen stating that unlocking the bootloader will void the warranty as well as void any insurance plan.[http://android.modaco.com/content/google-nexus-one-nexusone-modaco-com/299078/how-to-unlock-the-bootloader-on-your-nexus-one/ How to unlock the bootloader on your Nexus One - Android @ MoDaCo] The popular [[CyanogenMod]] build of [[Android (operating system)|Android]] has already been released for the device.{{cite web|url=http://androidcommunity.com/cyanogenmod-5-0-rom-for-nexus-one-released-20100202/ |title=CyanogenMod 5.0 ROM for Nexus One released|publisher=Android Community |date=2010-01-02 |accessdate=2001-01-02}} Hidden menus can be accessed by dialling the following numbers: {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align: left" |- style="text-align: left" |*#*#info#*#* or *#*#4636#*#* |"Testing" menu on the Nexus One and most other Android devices.{{cite web|url=http://www.androidcentral.com/how-force-nexus-one-3g-mode|title=How to: Force Nexus One into 3G mode|author=Phil Nickinson|date=13Jan2010|publisher=Android Central|accessdate=2010-05-14}} It will bring up 4 categories: Phone Information, Battery Information, Battery History, and Usage Statistics. Also allows for disabling of the phone's cellular radio. |- |*#*#checkin#*#* or *#*#2432546#*#* |Force an immediate search for patches and updates. |- |*#*#talk#*#* or *#*#8255#*#* |GTalkService info |- |245# |Load Contacts from SIM card |} ==Comparison with other phones== Though the [[multi-touch]] experience of the Nexus One is generally similar to that of other multi-touch enabled smartphones (iPhone, Palm Pre, etc), the Nexus One hardware uses software to "enable" multi-touch ability, resulting in x/y axis confusion and preventing some multi-touch applications (e.g. games) from working as they should, compared to other phones.[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qzhUzq6bTPg YouTube - Motorola Droid vs Nexus One: Multitouch Test] As of an update released February 2, 2010{{cite web|title=Nexus One Update Announcement|publisher= googlenexusoneboard.blogspot.com|url=http://googlenexusoneboard.blogspot.com/2010/02/new-software-update-for-nexus-one.html|date=2010-02-02|accessdate=2010-02-04}} it has pinch-to-zoom functionality in the phone's Browser, Gallery and Maps applications. In addition to these official applications, 3rd party apps that support multi-touch gestures are available. ===HTC Desire=== {{Main|HTC Desire}} HTC later released the HTC Desire, which has very similar specifications to the Nexus One. The Desire features an optical trackpad rather than a trackball, physical buttons rather than the touch sensitive buttons and an FM radio but lacks the noise cancelling dual microphones present in the Nexus One. The Desire is solely branded as HTC and runs [[HTC Sense]] rather than the stock version of Android. Sense can be switched off to get the stock Android experience however this was disabled on the retail HTC Desire.[http://www.androidcentral.com/htc-desire-goes-sense-less-and-turns-nexus-one AndroidCentral] ==Reception== * The Android 2.2 update caused the Nexus One to develop a serious Wi-Fi connectivity issue which causes the Wi-Fi to continually lose its connection and fail to reconnect.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/android/thread?tid=461352ddadac96d2&hl=en |title=Whats wrong with the Nexus ONe's WiFi ?!?!!!!!}}{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/android/thread?tid=75896215b18c3d6d&hl=en |title=Nexus 1 WiFi connectivity problems: hot spots signal too low even I am near those devices.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/android/thread?tid=3d253758857e6f67&hl=en |title=Nexus One will not connect to wifi network}}{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/android/thread?tid=670e46135cadce1e&hl=en |title=Nexus one cant connect to wifi}} There are reports that Android 2.2.1 has fixed this issue, although there has been no official word from Google. * The Nexus One reportedly had problems with 3G connectivity and touchscreen at launch.{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2010/01/google-nexus-customers-sour/ |title=Google Nexus One Leaves Customers Sour |publisher=[[Wired News]] |date=2010-01-12 |accessdate=2010-02-07|quote=''Since its introduction last week, support forums have been busily documenting customer problems, mostly 3G service issues, which T-Mobile USA has acknowledged. Google admits it offers no telephone support and can take three days to answer e-mails.''}} Updates have since been issued for the operating system, including the addition of multi-touch abilities in the Android web browser and Google Maps functions. While the updates have reportedly also somewhat improved 3G connectivity for the T-Mobile USA version of the device, similar issues with the AT&T compatible version have not yet been addressed. A class action lawsuit is pending against Google on the matter, as the phone has problems connecting to 3G networks in areas with less than ideal coverage. * Initially, Google did not provide telephone support and consumers were forced to use its online Android forum.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/186643/support_problems_good_reason_to_avoid_nexus_one.html |title=Support Problems Good Reason to Avoid Nexus One |publisher=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] |date=2010-01-11 |accessdate=2010-02-07|quote=''Since its introduction last week, support forums have been busily documenting customer problems, mostly 3G service issues, which T-Mobile USA has acknowledged. Google admits it offers no telephone support and can take three days to answer e-mails.''}} At this time, Google has stopped all support for the phone and customers are directed to contact HTC. * The Nexus One is currently shipped to the US, the UK, Hong Kong, Germany and Singapore, although the phone has not been fully localized for non-US markets - the lack of [[satnav]] outside the US,[http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/Google+Mobile/thread?tid=5f5674323c92ca9e&hl=en Why is Google Nav is only available in USA - Google Mobile Help] UK{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/google/7614487/Google-unveils-satnav-for-Android-phones.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Google unveils satnav for Android phones | first=Matt | last=Warman | date=April 21, 2010}} and Ireland,[http://www.siliconrepublic.com/news/article/15952/digital-life/free-sat-nav-for-irish-android-users Google launches free sat nav for Irish Android users - News - News | siliconrepublic.com - Ireland's Technology News Service] and the US English "voice keyboard"[http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/android/thread?tid=3b2245afbb9bdf78&hl=en UK voice input - Android Help] being the most obvious shortcomings. Recent update saw Google Navigation being enabled for additional 11 countries.[http://googlemobile.blogspot.com/2010/06/fun-on-autobahn-google-maps-navigation.html Fun on the Autobahn: Google Maps Navigation in 11 more Countries - Official Google Mobile Blog] * [[Goldman Sachs]] slashed their estimates for sales of the phone in 2010 by 70% due to the half-hearted marketing efforts by carriers.{{cite web|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/03/11/nexus_one_sales/|title=Carrier apathy depresses Google Phone outlook}} ==Support== On July 16, 2010, Google announced that the next shipment of Nexus One smartphones would be the last to be sold on their web store, stating "While the global adoption of the Android platform has exceeded our expectations, the web store has not. Itâs remained a niche channel for early adopters, but itâs clear that many customers like a hands-on experience before buying a phone."{{cite news|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/05/nexus-one-changes-in-availability.html |title=Nexus One changes in availability}} The device will continue to be sold through retail stores, and other channel partners.[http://android-developers.blogspot.com/2010/08/nexus-one-developer-phone.html Android Developers Blog: Nexus One Developer Phone]{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/TECH/mobile/07/19/nexus.one.discontinued/index.html?iref=NS1#fbid=nPeDbHV_wpr |title=Google quietly kills its once-hyped Nexus One phone |first=Doug |last=Gross |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=July 19, 2010 |accessdate=August 8, 2010}} As of November 1, 2010 Google have closed the Nexus One support forums, redirecting users to the Google Mobile forum, which only has categories for software. The message shown to users was: "The Nexus One forum will be archived and become read-only on November 1st. Please see the Nexus One Terms of Sale for details regarding support. If you have questions about using applications on your Nexus One post them to the Google Mobile Forum."{{cite news |url=http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/android?hl=en |title=Android Help |date=October 25, 2010}} Also worthy of note is that the link to Terms of Sale on that message has no mention of support, contrary to what the message implies. As of the announcement of Android 4.0, Ice Cream Sandwich, HTC has announced that there will be no more software updates for the Nexus One, as the hardware is now too old to run the new version of Android effectively.{{cite web|last=Warman|first=Matt|title=Android upgrade for Google Nexus S âin weeksâ|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/google/8848669/Android-upgrade-for-Google-Nexus-S-in-weeks.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=5 November 2011}} ==Nexus S== {{Main|Nexus S}} According to [[Andy Rubin]], the next Nexus series phone would have targeted business users and may have had a hardware keyboard.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE60809H20100109 |title=Next version of Nexus will be enterprise phone |publisher=Reuters |date= January 9, 2010|accessdate=2010-01-18 | first=Sinead | last=Carew}} In July 2010, ''The Daily Telegraph'' reported in an interview with CEO [[Eric Schmidt]] that Google would not be releasing a follow up to the Nexus One.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/google/7864223/Googles-Eric-Schmidt-You-can-trust-us-with-your-data.html |publisher=Telegraph |accessdate=2010-07-04 | location=London | title=Google's Eric Schmidt: You can trust us with your data | first=Shane | last=Richmond | date=July 1, 2010}} However, on November 11, 2010, Engadget leaked some pictures of a [[Samsung]] manufactured [[Nexus S]] device along with marketing materials from [[Best Buy]] and [[T-Mobile USA]] in the United States.{{cite news|url=http://www.engadget.com/2010/11/11/this-is-the-nexus-s/ |title=This is the Nexus S |publisher=Engadget |date= November 11, 2010|accessdate=2010-11-11}} Google officially announced the Nexus S on December 6, 2010. The device, built by Samsung, was the first to ship with Android OS version 2.3 "Gingerbread" and includes [[Near Field Communication]] (NFC) hardware. == See also == * [[HTC Desire]] * [[List of HTC phones]] * [[List of Android devices]] * [[Comparison of smartphones]] * [[Comparison of Android devices]] == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.htc.com/www/support/nexusone/ Official HTC Support] * [http://www.google.com/phone/detail/nexus-one Official Nexus One specifications] === Reviews === * {{Cite news|first=Andrew|last=Johnson|url=http://googlenexuscellphone.com/nexus-one-vs-i-phone-and-the-rest/|accessdate=January 5, 2010|title=Google Nexus One vs iPhone vs Others|newspaper=[[MobileWorld]]|publisher=[[MobileWorld]]|date=January 5, 2010}} * {{Cite news|first=Michael|last=Arrington|url=http://www.techcrunch.com/2010/01/05/google-nexus-one-the-techcrunch-review/|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Google Nexus One: The TechCrunch Review|newspaper=[[TechCrunch]]|publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|date=January 5, 2010}} * {{Cite news|first=Rahul|last=Srinivas|url=http://www.techtree.com/India/Reviews/Battle_Royale_iPhone_Vs_Nexus_One/551-108528-614.html|accessdate=January 6, 2010|title=Battle Royale: iPhone Vs. Nexus One|newspaper=[[Techtree]]|publisher=[[Techtree]]|date=January 6, 2010}} ===Videos=== * [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I6COwgigJ-g Official Nexus One Video] , [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e2WtBwAL0SE Concept & Design] * [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tuVyExV8SYo Youtube comparison with iPhone] , [http://cnettv.cnet.com/nexus-one-vs-iphone-3gs/9742-1_53-50083136.html cnet comparison] * [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f_ETSvTAo4A Google sponsored Ninja unboxing - Entertainment video] * [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RfqwKa4bT74 Nexus One Screen Scratch Test] * [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pIcSQZvb6pg Nexus One Dis-assembly] ===Other=== * [http://tech.shantanugoel.com/2010/05/23/android-froyo-nexus-one.html Android Froyo And Nexus One: Everything We Know] * [http://googlenexusapp.blogspot.com/p/goolge.html Nexus One Pros & Cons] * [http://torvalds-family.blogspot.com/2010/02/happy-camper.html Linus Torvalds: Nexus One is a winner] * [http://googlenexuscellphone.com/google-nexus-one-review/ Nexus One Review By Daniel Levi] * [http://www.pixelfarm.nl/phones/nexusone/ Nexus One 3D model] * [http://www.googlenexusoneblog.com Nexus One Video Blog] {{Android}} {{Android devices}} {{Google Inc.}} [[Category:Smartphones]] [[Category:Google]] [[Category:Android devices]] [[Category:Digital audio players]] [[Category:Portable media players]] [[Category:Touchscreen portable media players]] [[Category:GPS navigation devices]] [[Category:2010 introductions]] [[ar:ÙÙØ³Ø³ ÙÙ]] [[be-x-old:Nexus One]] [[ca:Nexus One]] [[da:Nexus One]] [[de:Nexus One]] [[es:Nexus One]] [[fa:ÙÚ©Ø³ÙØ³ ÙØ§Ù]] [[fr:Nexus One]] [[ko:ë¥ìì¤ ì]] [[hi:à¤¨à¥à¤à¥à¤¸à¤¸ à¤µà¤¨]] [[it:Nexus One]] [[lt:Nexus One]] [[hu:Nexus One]] [[ml:à´¨àµà´àµà´¸à´¸àµ à´µàµº]] [[nl:Nexus One]] [[ja:Nexus One]] [[no:Nexus One]] [[pl:Nexus One]] [[pt:Nexus One]] [[ru:Nexus One]] [[simple:Nexus One]] [[sk:Nexus One]] [[fi:Nexus One]] [[sv:Nexus One]] [[tr:Nexus One]] [[uk:Nexus One]] [[zh:Nexus One]]
